facts.text: The respondent company dismissed three of its workmen between the 15th December, 1959 and 6th January, 1960.
The respondent company retrenched another employee, Shri Mohinder Singh, Booking Clerk, on the 7th February 1960.

The District Motor Transport Workers Union raised a dispute with the management on the 17th November, 1960 and demanded the reinstatement of the dismissed workmen as well as the payment of retrenchment compensation regarding the workman who was retrenched.
Conciliation having failed, the State Government was approached for making a reference of the dispute for adjudication.
On the 9th June, 1960, the State Government declined to make a reference.

A further attempt was made to persuade the State Government... but that attempt also failed, as will be seen from the order dated the 29th July 1961. In this order, the State Government had stated that out of sixty workmen employed in the concern, only 18 workmen had supported the demand and these 18 included thirteen dismissed workers of the company.
Out of the 18 workmen who espoused the cause, only five were in the employment of the respondent company and thirteen others were workmen who had already been dismissed from service.

The State Government made a reference for adjudication to the Labour Court, Rohtak, by order dated the 5th March, 1962, referring the following two questions: Whether termination of services of Sarvashri Manmohan Singh, Jagir Singh and Inderjit Singh is justified and in order? If not, to what relief they are entitled? Whether the retrenchment of Shri Mohinder Singh, Booking Clerk, is justified, and in order? If not, to what relief he is entitled?

When the Labour Court commenced the proceedings, the management raised preliminary objection that the dispute referred was not an industrial dispute under section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act as the cause had not been espoused by a substantial body of the workmen.
The Labour Court overruled the preliminary objection and accepted that it was an industrial dispute.

The company filed a writ petition in the High Court for quashing the order of the Labour Court and the reference. The learned single Judge held the reference incompetent as not sponsored by substantial body of workmen.
The workmen did not challenge the single Judge's decision. The State challenged it in Letters Patent Appeal No. 108 of 1966 before Division Bench.
Division Bench confirmed the single Judge's order on 10th September, 1968, holding the reference incompetent.
On the 17th November, 1960, when espousal was made, there were sixty workmen in the employ of the respondent company. The demand was supported by 18 workmen: five in employ and thirteen dismissed.
No plea that any union representative of the workmen took up the dispute.

legal_issues.text: Whether the dispute referred by the State Government was an industrial dispute under section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, as the cause of the workmen had been espoused by a substantial body of the workmen of the company.

petitioner_arguments.text: Five out of sixty workmen espousing the cause is sufficient to constitute espousal by a substantial or appreciable body of workmen, as in Workmen of Rohtak General Transport Company v. Rohtak General Transport Company where five out of twenty-two was held sufficient.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Workmen of Rohtak General Transport Company v. Rohtak General Transport Company, 1962 1 LLJ 634

respondent_arguments.text: The dispute is not an industrial dispute under section 2(k) as only five out of sixty workmen (1/12th) espoused the cause, which is not a substantial body.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act

court_reasoning.text: Even applying the ratio of the Rohtak case, five out of sixty (1/12th) is a very low proportion and cannot be considered espousal by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Such an espousal cannot be considered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen so as to constitute the dispute an industrial dispute.

court_reasoning.text: The Rohtak decision is distinguishable because there were resolutions passed by all employees and material showing union took up the cause, which management did not challenge; here no such union or resolutions pleaded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The sponsoring by the 13 dismissed employees will have to be left out of consideration. If so, we are left with the position that the espousal of the dispute was only by five out of sixty employees.

court_reasoning.text: No plea before Tribunal that any union espoused the cause; Labour Court held no such plea taken.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be incompetent.

holdings.text: Espousal by only five out of sixty workmen does not constitute an industrial dispute under section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act.
The reference made by the State Government was incompetent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of Rohtak General Transport Company v. Rohtak General Transport Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by appellant to argue 5/22 espousal sufficient; court distinguished due to additional factors like resolutions and union support not present here.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines industrial dispute; requires espousal by substantial body of workmen for individual dispute to become industrial dispute.

outcome.summary: The appeal against the High Court judgment holding the State Government's reference incompetent due to absence of industrial dispute is dismissed.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs of the first respondent.

key_quotes.text: "Such an espousal, in our opinion, cannot be considered to be by an appreciable or substantial body of workmen so as to constitute the dispute an industrial dispute."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on what constitutes substantial espousal under s.2(k).

key_quotes.text: "The State Government will have jurisdiction to make a reference only if there is an Industrial Dispute. As there was no Industrial Dispute, the reference made by the State Government has been rightly held by the High Court to be, incompetent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains lack of jurisdiction for reference.
